content.heading: How to Convert kVA to kW
content.paragraph1: Converting kilovolt-amperes (kVA) to kilowatts (kW) is essential for electrical engineering, power system design, and understanding the relationship between apparent power and real power. kVA measures apparent power in AC circuits, while kW measures real power (actual work done). Our free kVA to kW calculator makes this conversion quick and easy.
content.paragraph2: The conversion formula is: kW = kVA × Power Factor, where kVA is the apparent power, Power Factor (PF) is a value between 0 and 1 that represents the efficiency of power usage, and kW is the real power. The power factor accounts for the phase difference between voltage and current in AC circuits. For example, if you have 10 kVA with a power factor of 0.85: kW = 10 × 0.85 = 8.5 kW.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is commonly used in: calculating real power consumption from apparent power ratings, determining actual power requirements for electrical equipment, analyzing power factor correction needs, sizing generators and UPS systems, designing electrical distribution systems, calculating energy costs and efficiency, selecting appropriate electrical components, and troubleshooting power quality issues. Knowing how to convert kVA to kW helps engineers, electricians, and technicians understand the actual power consumption and optimize electrical systems.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes kVA and power factor as inputs, automatically applies the conversion formula, and provides the result in kilowatts. The calculator also displays additional information including the input values and the complete formula for easy reference. Power factor values typically range from 0.8 to 0.95 for most electrical loads, with 1.0 representing perfect power factor (purely resistive loads). Whether you're working on residential, commercial, or industrial electrical projects, our kVA to kW calculator provides accurate, instant conversions.
content.exampleText: For 5 kVA with a power factor of 0.9: kW = 5 × 0.9 = 4.5 kW. For 50 kVA with a power factor of 0.85: kW = 50 × 0.85 = 42.5 kW. For 2.5 kVA with a power factor of 1.0 (resistive load): kW = 2.5 × 1.0 = 2.5 kW.

content.heading: How to Convert Kilowatts to Amps
content.paragraph1: Converting kilowatts (kW) to amperes (A) is essential for electrical engineering, circuit design, and selecting appropriate circuit breakers and wire sizes. The conversion depends on the voltage, phase type (DC, AC Single Phase, or AC Three Phase), and power factor for AC circuits. Our free kilowatts to amps calculator makes this conversion quick and easy.
content.paragraph2: The conversion formulas are: For DC: A = (kW × 1000) / V. For AC Single Phase: A = (kW × 1000) / (V × PF). For AC Three Phase: A = (kW × 1000) / (V × PF × √3). Where kW is power in kilowatts, V is voltage in volts, PF is power factor (0-1), and A is current in amperes. For example, for 10 kW at 240V DC: A = (10 × 1000) / 240 = 41.67 A.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is commonly used in: sizing circuit breakers and fuses, selecting appropriate wire gauges, designing electrical circuits, calculating current requirements for electrical equipment, determining load capacity for electrical systems, analyzing power distribution, selecting transformers and generators, and troubleshooting electrical issues. Understanding how to convert kilowatts to amps helps engineers, electricians, and technicians ensure safe and efficient electrical installations.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes power (kW), voltage (V), phase type, and power factor (for AC) as inputs, automatically applies the appropriate conversion formula, and provides the result in amperes. The calculator supports DC, AC Single Phase, and AC Three Phase systems. Power factor values typically range from 0.8 to 0.95 for most electrical loads, with 1.0 representing perfect power factor (purely resistive loads). Whether you're working on residential, commercial, or industrial electrical projects, our kilowatts to amps calculator provides accurate, instant conversions.
content.exampleText: For 5 kW at 120V DC: A = (5 × 1000) / 120 = 41.67 A. For 10 kW at 240V AC Single Phase with PF 0.85: A = (10 × 1000) / (240 × 0.85) = 49.02 A. For 20 kW at 400V AC Three Phase with PF 0.9: A = (20 × 1000) / (400 × 0.9 × √3) = 32.08 A.

content.exampleText: For a 5000 mAh battery at 3.7 V: Wh = (5000 × 3.7) / 1000 = 18.5 Wh. For a 3000 mAh battery at 12 V: Wh = (3000 × 12) / 1000 = 36 Wh. For a 10000 mAh battery at 5 V: Wh = (10000 × 5) / 1000 = 50 Wh.

content.heading: How to Use Ohm's Law Calculator
content.paragraph1: Ohm's Law is a fundamental principle in electrical engineering that describes the relationship between voltage (V), current (I), resistance (R), and power (P) in an electrical circuit. This law states that voltage equals current multiplied by resistance (V = I × R), and power equals voltage multiplied by current (P = V × I). Our free Ohm's Law calculator makes it easy to calculate any of these values when you know the other two.
content.paragraph2: The calculator supports all standard Ohm's Law formulas: V = I × R (voltage from current and resistance), I = V / R (current from voltage and resistance), R = V / I (resistance from voltage and current), P = V × I (power from voltage and current), P = I² × R (power from current and resistance), and P = V² / R (power from voltage and resistance). Simply enter any 2 values, and the calculator automatically calculates the remaining 2 values using the appropriate formulas.
content.paragraph3: This calculator is commonly used in: circuit design and analysis, electrical troubleshooting, selecting proper component values, understanding electrical relationships, calculating power consumption, designing electrical systems, verifying electrical calculations, and educational purposes. The calculator supports multiple unit prefixes including micro (μ), milli (m), kilo (k), and mega (M) for voltage, current, resistance, and power, making it versatile for various applications from microelectronics to power systems. Understanding Ohm's Law helps engineers, electricians, students, and hobbyists design safe and efficient electrical circuits.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes any 2 values as inputs, automatically applies the appropriate Ohm's Law formulas, and provides the remaining 2 values as results. The calculator displays the formulas used for each calculation, making it an excellent educational tool. Whether you're designing circuits, troubleshooting electrical problems, learning electrical concepts, or verifying calculations, our Ohm's Law calculator provides accurate, instant results with support for multiple unit prefixes.
content.exampleText: If you have a voltage of 12 V and a current of 2 A, the calculator will find: R = 12 / 2 = 6 Ω and P = 12 × 2 = 24 W. If you have a resistance of 100 Ω and a power of 50 W, the calculator will find: V = √(50 × 100) = 70.71 V and I = √(50 / 100) = 0.707 A. If you have a voltage of 5 V and a resistance of 10 Ω, the calculator will find: I = 5 / 10 = 0.5 A and P = 5² / 10 = 2.5 W.

content.heading: How to Calculate Wire Gauge
content.paragraph1: Wire gauge calculation is essential for safe electrical installations, ensuring that wires can safely carry the required current without excessive voltage drop or overheating. The American Wire Gauge (AWG) system is the standard method for specifying wire sizes in North America. Our free wire gauge calculator helps you determine the correct wire size based on current, length, voltage drop, circuit type, and wire material.
content.paragraph2: The calculation process involves: determining the required resistance based on voltage drop and current (R = V_drop / I for DC, R = V_drop / (I × √3) for AC three-phase), calculating the required cross-section area using resistivity and length (A = ρ × L / R), and finding the appropriate AWG size that meets or exceeds the required area. The calculator supports both copper and aluminum wires, with copper having lower resistivity (0.0172 Ω·mm²/m) than aluminum (0.0282 Ω·mm²/m).
content.paragraph3: This calculator is commonly used in: electrical installations and wiring, circuit design and analysis, selecting proper wire sizes for safety, calculating voltage drop in long wire runs, sizing wires for motors and equipment, designing power distribution systems, ensuring code compliance, and preventing electrical fires. Proper wire sizing is critical for safety, as undersized wires can overheat and cause fires, while oversized wires waste material and increase costs unnecessarily.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes current, length, voltage drop, circuit type (DC, AC single-phase, or AC three-phase), and wire material (copper or aluminum) as inputs, automatically calculates the required resistance and cross-section area, and provides the appropriate AWG size along with the actual cross-section area and resistance. The calculator displays the formulas used for each calculation, making it an excellent educational tool. Whether you're installing electrical wiring, designing circuits, sizing wires for equipment, or learning about electrical systems, our wire gauge calculator provides accurate, instant results.
content.exampleText: If you have a 20 A current, 50 m length, 3 V voltage drop, DC circuit, and copper wire, the calculator will find: Required resistance R = 3 V / 20 A = 0.15 Ω, Required area A = 0.0172 × 50 m / 0.15 Ω = 5.73 mm², and appropriate AWG = 10 (5.26 mm², which is close enough). For a 30 A current, 100 ft length, 5 V voltage drop, AC three-phase circuit, and aluminum wire: Required resistance R = 5 V / (30 A × 1.732) = 0.0962 Ω, Required area A = 0.0282 × 30.48 m / 0.0962 Ω = 8.94 mm², and appropriate AWG = 8 (8.37 mm²).
